docs.lead_paragraph: A long-spreading gap between the wages of undereducated workers in menial jobs and those of skilled college graduates is contributing to another gap, in workers' health benefits, a research journal reports. Lending a new perspective on the swelling numbers of Americans without health insurance, an article to be published on Monday in the journal Health Affairs says that a phenomenon feeding the benefits gap is the proliferation of low-wage businesses, like stores and restaurants.

headline.main: Low-Wage Businesses Add to Number of Uninsured Workers

docs.abstract: Report in Health Affairs research journal says long-spreading gap between wages of undereducated workers in menial jobs and those of skilled college graduates is contributing to another gap in workers' health benefits; says phenomenon feeding benefits gap is proliferation of low-wage businesses; says wages of high school graduates fell 11 percent from 1973 to 1997, while those of college graduates rose 17 percent; says rise in numbers of uninsured Amnericans, from 38 million in 1992 to 43 million in 1997, has touched most segments of population, but poor especially (S)
docs.snippet: A long-spreading gap between the wages of undereducated workers in menial jobs and those of skilled college graduates is contributing to another gap, in workers' health benefits, a research journal reports.    Lending a new perspective on the...

docs.lead_paragraph: THE conventional wisdom these days is that any major change to Social Security is unlikely before next year's elections, but Robert M. Ball remains ever vigilant. In the unending debate over the nation's pension system, Mr. Ball stands as the great defender of traditional Social Security, the genius of its basic principles, the soundness of its basic approach. ''Though I feel good about our position,'' he said in a lull in the struggle on a lazy spring afternoon, ''people who think like I do better be very careful, and we better have good proposals and we better be alert. Or something may happen that we don't like.''

headline.main: A Great Defender of the Old Social Security Battles On

docs.abstract: Interview with Robert M Ball, former Social Security Commissioner who has remained staunch defender of retirement system; he is regular source of advice for leading Congressional Democrats and has sent several memorandums on issue to White House over last few years (Public Lives column) (M)
docs.snippet: THE conventional wisdom these days is that any major change to Social Security is unlikely before next year's elections, but Robert M. Ball remains ever vigilant. In the unending debate over the nation's pension system, Mr. Ball stands as the great...

docs.lead_paragraph: It is spelled out, right there in the code of ethics of the Association for Computing Machinery, one of the world's oldest and largest computer professional societies: ''An essential aim of computer professionals is to minimize negative consequences of computer systems, including threats to health and safety.'' Computer professionals, the code continues, should warn their bosses about any such threats and even blow the whistle if their superiors ignore them.

headline.main: For Coders, a Code of Conduct; 2000 Problem Tests Professionalism of Programmers

docs.abstract: Year 2000 problem gives new life to debate about whether computer programmers should be required to obtain professional certification; it could become legal as well as ethical question if, as expected, computer problems lead to widespread lawsuits; just how much programmers and their managers should be faulted for Y2K is one of questions being raised about profession that usually labors in obscurity but plays increasingly vital role in society; Paul A Strassmann, former chief information officer for Defense Dept and Xerox Corp, says there will no longer be unconstrained trust in what information technologists can deliver; some experts disagree, saying millennium bug is testament to how well programmers did their job, writing software that has lasted far longer than anticipated; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: People who hope to slim down with the help of Xenical, a newly approved weight-loss drug, may have to pay for it themselves. A number of managed care companies are categorizing Xenical as a life style product that they will cover only in exceptional cases -- for overweight people at risk for cardiovascular problems, or those with diabetes, breathing problems or brittle bones. Even so, analysts said, many people are likely to pay the $4 or $5 a day themselves needed to buy Xenical, a treatment made by Roche Holding A.G. of Switzerland. Analysts projected peak worldwide sales of the drug at $600 million to as much as $3 billion a year.

headline.main: Diet Drug May Face A Tough Sell At H.M.O.'s

docs.abstract: Several managed care companies categorize Xenical, newly approved weight-loss drug, as life style product that they will cover only in exceptional cases, for overweight people at risk of cardiovascular problems or other serious problems; analysts expect many people to pay for Xenical themselves, at cost of $4 or $5 per day (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: FOR one Yonkers mother, the turning point came when she could not read a bedtime story to her 4-year-old son. For a White Plains construction worker, it came when he was unable to fill out a health insurance form. A recent immigrant from China made her decision after she came home weeping from an open house at her daughter's school in Ossining because she had not understood a word, spoken or written. What each of these people -- and thousands like them -- did next was enroll in a literacy class. The goal: to gain the skills that would help them understand information that is basic to everyday life -- like a note from a child's teacher, a test for a driver's license or a form in a doctor's office.

headline.main: Literacy Groups: Filling One of Life's Needs

docs.lead_paragraph: Transplant surgeons who once concentrated on vital organs like hearts, livers and kidneys are branching out, transplanting an array of body parts with surprising success, and possibly heralding a day when tissues not essential to life are routinely given to others. To the astonishment of many experts, the two men recently given new hands in Lyon, France, and Louisville, Ky., are progressing well, without rejection crises. With less publicity, surgeons elsewhere have successfully performed experimental knee, larynx, trachea, femur, nerve and muscle transplants.

headline.main: New Direction for Transplants Raises Hopes and Questions
headline.kicker: REBUILDING THE BODY: A SPECIAL REPORT.

docs.abstract: Special Report: Rebuilding the Body; transplant surgeons who once concentrated on vital organs like hearts, livers and kidneys are branching out, transplanting an array of body parts with surprising success, and possibly heralding a new day when tissues not essential to life are routinely given to others; to the astonishment of many experts, two men recently given new hands in Lyon, France, and Louisville, Ky, are progressing well, without rejection crises; with less publicity, surgeons elsewhere have successfully performed experimental knee, larynx, trachea, femur, nerve and muscle transplants; the new transplants are believed to be few--no central orgn keeps a tally; and there is no way to know how may people will benefit from them if they prove successful in the long term; examples cited; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Even the good time rock-and-roll that Bob Tomassone was playing for the Friday-night crowd at Coach's Sports Bar & Grille on Allyn Street seemed to refer to how Hartford had lost the Patriots. It was a song by Rod Stewart, something about a girl named Maggie, who had played with the heart of a young man and left him feeling used. ''Maggie I wish I'd never seen your face,'' Mr. Tomassone sang. Then he stopped strumming his guitar and asked, ''Hey didn't that song kind of remind you of what the Patriots did?'' And the crowd let out a primal moan of pain.

headline.main: Feeling Used, Hartford Residents Sing the Blues Over News

docs.abstract: Residents of Hartford, Conn, feel city was used as bargaining chip by New England Patriots in wider negotiation to win better terms to remain in Foxboro, Mass; many blame Gov John Rowland for losing team--as well as Patriots' owner Robert K Kraft, City of Boston, National Football League and universe; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: About two years ago, Matt Hazard and three of his buddies got together to form a new, hard-rock band in Minneapolis. At a loss for what to call themselves, they settled on Moral Hazard. ''The guitarist wanted to get my last name in the band because we thought it sounded cool, but every combination seemed kind of lame,'' recalls the 19-year-old Mr. Hazard. ''But we were all in the same high school economics class, and one day our teacher began writing that term on the board and we said, 'That's it.' ''
docs.abstract: Article discusses economic cases of 'moral hazard,' situation in which risky behavior is encouraged because risk takers believe they will be bailed out by third party, as in financial crises in Asia and Russia; investors badly misjudged situation, lost money and stampeded for exits, leaving IMF and US Treasury to ponder aid that would help countries out of meltdown but also reward imprudent investors; other cases of moral hazard include savings-and-loan debacle in US, and even major league baseball: American League pitchers tend to throw more bean balls at batters, possibly because designated hitter rule leaves them safe from retribution at plate (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In one bold stroke, Tennessee converted its Medicaid health benefits to managed care five years ago and used the savings to cover hundreds of thousands of people who could not afford health insurance of their own or were too sick to qualify. With three million people enrolled, the program, called Tenncare, became the most ambitious and generous government health plan in the nation. But with Tenncare's costs rising and Tennessee facing a budget deficit, the program is under fire and facing probable retrenchment under pressure from Gov. Don Sundquist. And the people most at risk are those who benefit most from the state's effort at providing nearly universal health insurance: those with chronic or even terminal diseases who have been rejected by private insurance.

headline.main: Tennessee Talks of Paring Plan for 'Uninsurables'

docs.abstract: Tennessee's program for people who cannot afford health insurance or are too sick to qualify is under fire and facing probable retrenchment under pressure to cut rising costs; Gov Don Sondquist has called for moratorium on new enrollments of those seen as uninsurable while state explores cutting benefits, raising premiums and tightening eligibility in nation's most ambitious and generous government health plan; Brian Lapps Sr, Tenncare director, holds some of poorest recipients could help pay for program by giving up nonessentials, interview; photo (M)
